title: cambridgema vs ggplot2 Default Colors

title: Getting Started with cambridgema
text: cambridgema package provides nature-inspired color palettes based flora seasons Cambridge, Massachusetts.
code: library(cambridgema) library(ggplot2)

title: Getting Started with cambridgema
text: package includes three types palettes: Categorical (5 colors): spring, summer, autumn, winter, river Sequential (7 colors): crimson_seq, river_seq, foliage_seq Diverging (9 colors): crimson_blue, brick_pine
code: list_palettes() #> $categorical #> [1] "spring" "summer" "autumn" "winter" "river"  #>  #> $sequential #> [1] "crimson_seq" "river_seq"   "foliage_seq" #>  #> $diverging #> [1] "crimson_blue" "brick_pine"

text: Diverging palettes automatically center zero - perfect correlations:
code: # Create correlation matrix cor_mat <- cor(mtcars[, 1:6]) cor_df <- as.data.frame(as.table(cor_mat)) names(cor_df) <- c("Var1", "Var2", "value")  ggplot(cor_df, aes(Var1, Var2, fill = value)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_cam("crimson_blue") +   labs(title = "Correlation Matrix with Crimson-Blue Diverging Palette") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Getting Started with cambridgema
text: functions support reverse parameter:
code: # Normal order ggplot(iris, aes(Species, Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot() +   scale_fill_cam("spring") +   labs(title = "Spring Palette (Normal Order)") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "none") # Reversed order ggplot(iris, aes(Species, Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot() +   scale_fill_cam("spring", reverse = TRUE) +   labs(title = "Spring Palette (Reversed)") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Getting Started with cambridgema
text: Missing data uses neutral granite_gray default. Customize na.value:
code: df <- data.frame(   x = 1:5,   y = c(2, 3, NA, 4, 5),   g = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E") )  ggplot(df, aes(x, y, color = g)) +   geom_point(size = 5) +   scale_color_cam("spring", na.value = "#F0F5F9") +   labs(title = "Missing Value Shown in Snow White") +   theme_minimal() #> Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`).

title: Check palette colorblind accessibility — check_colorblind
text: Evaluates color palette distinguishability three types color vision deficiency: deuteranopia, protanopia, tritanopia. Uses CIE LAB color space calculate perceptual color distances.

title: Check palette colorblind accessibility — check_colorblind
code: check_colorblind(palette, min_dist = 10)

title: Check palette colorblind accessibility — check_colorblind
text: palette Character vector hex colors, palette name min_dist Minimum acceptable color distance CIE LAB space. Default 10, generally distinguishable people.

title: Check palette colorblind accessibility — check_colorblind
text: list accessibility scores including: passes: Logical, TRUE palette passes accessibility check normal: Minimum pairwise distance normal vision deuteranopia: Distance red-green deficiency (~6\ protanopia: Distance red deficiency (~2\ tritanopia: Distance blue-yellow deficiency (rare)

title: Check palette colorblind accessibility — check_colorblind
code: # Check built-in palette check_colorblind("spring") #> Colorblind Accessibility Check #> ------------------------------ #> Status: PASS  #> Threshold: 10  #>  #> Minimum color distances: #>   Normal vision:   35.49  #>   Deuteranopia:    16.58 (red-green, ~6% males) #>   Protanopia:      22.81 (red, ~2% males) #>   Tritanopia:      22.3 (blue-yellow, rare)  # Check custom colors check_colorblind(c("#FF0000", "#00FF00", "#0000FF")) #> Colorblind Accessibility Check #> ------------------------------ #> Status: PASS  #> Threshold: 10  #>  #> Minimum color distances: #>   Normal vision:   170.57  #>   Deuteranopia:    27.96 (red-green, ~6% males) #>   Protanopia:      65.74 (red, ~2% males) #>   Tritanopia:      71.6 (blue-yellow, rare)  # Stricter threshold check_colorblind("autumn", min_dist = 15) #> Colorblind Accessibility Check #> ------------------------------ #> Status: FAIL  #> Threshold: 15  #>  #> Minimum color distances: #>   Normal vision:   28.82  #>   Deuteranopia:    9.87 (red-green, ~6% males) #>   Protanopia:      7.34 (red, ~2% males) #>   Tritanopia:      18.09 (blue-yellow, rare)

title: Cambridge color scale for ggplot2 — scale_color_cam
code: library(ggplot2)  # Categorical palette for discrete data ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Width, Sepal.Length, color = Species)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_cam("autumn")   # Sequential palette for continuous data ggplot(faithfuld, aes(waiting, eruptions, fill = density)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_cam("river_seq", discrete = FALSE)   # Diverging palette for centered data (correlations, differences) # Automatically centers on zero df <- data.frame(x = 1:9, y = 1:9, z = seq(-1, 1, length.out = 9)) ggplot(df, aes(x, y, fill = z)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_cam("crimson_blue")
